body: okay - travis ci passed this time

@ladyVader @jhuynh1 @upthewaterspout @boglesby

Precheckin green.
Closing the pull rquest after your comments.

I would like to get a better understanding of the new feature first. So before the "export data" is export data of a specific region on a specific member to a file. All three options are mandatory. Now it seems I can export data of all regions on a specific member, so I should be able to do this:
gfsh> export data --member=abc --dir=xxx

Would the existence of --dir option implicitly mean "--parallel" already? do we need --parallel at all?
Closing for no activity.
@kohlmu-pivotal @pivotal-amurmann @WireBaron

I have pushed new commits, which contain changes suggested by reviewers, these changes include:
-"parallel" option defaults to value of "true" is option specified with no value
-handle gracefully issue of gfsh command created on member with different version of geode (will result in failed import/export)
-refactoring to improve DRYness of gfsh commands
-Remove base class from tests (incorporate setup code in each test, individually)
-change "directory" option to "dir"
Note that travis found a code formatting problem that can be fixed by running spotlessApply.

I think a user might think that they need to use --file to give the filename and --dir to give the directory of that file. So ignoring the --file and just using --dir might be confusing. Since we want them to use one or the other, but not both, I think the command should enforce that instead of ignoring one of them.
@pivotal-amurmann I split out a helper function and added some comments. Hopefully this should be clearer now.

I've added the test org.apache.geode.cache30.CacheXmlNotFoundUnitTest#testCacheXmlNotFoundInRealLog. It tests that an error about missing cache-xml file is indeed printed in the text log file, specified via "log-file" parameter. 
The existing test org.apache.geode.cache30.CacheXml66DUnitTest#testNonExistentFile() is supposed to test the same, but actually it doesn't. It only checks for an CacheXmlException exception to be thrown.
@jaredjstewart do you see any problems with these changes?

It's inappropriate to change the meaning of member-timeout like this.  All timeouts in the distributed-system settings are currently settings concerning other members.  Instead I think you should deprecate member-timeout, ack-wait-threshold and ack-severe-alert-threshold.  Add a new setting and base internal ack-wait-threshold & ack-severe-alert-threshold as multiples of that setting.  You've brought the discussion to the dev list & I think that's a good place to hammer out the details.

Also, don't modify InternalDistributedMember.  Put any new member information in NetView.  InternalDistributedMembers are serialized in a lot of messages and are already way too big.  That affects performance.

There's a page describing on-wire backward compatibility under Code Contributions on the wiki: https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/GEODE/Managing+Backward+Compatibility
That describes the toDataPre stuff that Dan was talking about.

This page describes how to write backward compatibility tests: https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/GEODE/Writing+Backward-compatibility+DUnit+tests
You can find examples in the repo by searching for uses of the class VersionManager.
@pivotal-amurmann
The `if (!isEntryExpiryPossible())` check could be combined with the  `if (!isInitialized())` just above it, but otherwise, looks good to me.

Lets hold off on merging this one for now. Some discussions are going on about adding this feature to the product (i.e. a hard limit on how much memory a region can use). If we decide we need that feature then I think it would make sense to use this existing config parameter instead of adding a new one.

I know that this is a VERY broad request.. but I think we should try and fulfill the following (from 12 Factor App development) https://12factor.net/logs
If our logging cannot fulfill this requirement then we need to address them.

@kohlmu-pivotal If my interpretation of the 12-factor app is correct (big IF right here) then this would mean that we should stop writing to a log file and instead write to stdout or stderr and something like fluentd would be concerned with writing those to a file. After some initial resistance I've come to very much like that approach and it works really well in cloud environments and is the way we should be doing it to best play with PCF. However, this comes down to using the correct log4j appender. That seems a little bit outside this story's scope though. I'll create a chore to investigate if customers can configure GF to properly log to stdout and run Gf as a proper 12-factor app.
This pull request need to be re-created
Please do not review yet, as the ticket may change after the discussion is over on the dev thread and we will have to implement the same behavior for the synchronous update of the indexes too.

precheckin green.
precheckin green.

Hi @jaredjstewart I don't actually see the change to the gradle file that is going to include this in geode-junit. Also, it seems that the $GEODE_HOME/lib dir does not contain geode-junit. Most of the users are going to configure maven/gradle for getting the geode-junit jar, so this probably is not a huge issue.

@sbawaska The change that includes this in geode-junit was to move the source files from geode-assembly/src/test/ into geode-junit/src/main/.  Geode-junit doesn't end up in $GEODE_HOME/lib, so I think that behavior is expected.  

The way I envision this rule to be used is one of the following:
1) For use inside of Geode (i.e. tests inside of geode-assembly), the Gradle build sets $GEODE_HOME to point at geode-assembly/build/install/apache-geode.
2) For external users, get the geode-junit jar through gradle/maven, and have $GEODE_HOME set to point at an existing Geode installation.
3) For external users, get the geode-junit jar through gradle/maven in addition to the full apache-geode distribution zip file from our snapshot repo.  I'm planning to write a Gradle task (doesn't exist yet) that will extract that distribution zip and set $GEODE_HOME to the expanded location (similar to what happens in 1 for internal usage).

I should note that 2 & 3 are certainly experimental at this time.

I think we should just go ahead and merge this. If we reuse an old parameter that had no meaning for some new feature, then people will think that the old releases also had that feature.

@kohlmu-pivotal I had a talk with @PivotalSarge and I think we'd rather make the `register` method private. It won't work at present, because there's only one serialization type available and that's registered whenever the `geode-protobuf` JAR is loaded (always), and... YAGNI. Or, we can add the method to the public API when it's usable.

Looks like I've missed adding stats to the handshaker. Perhaps we can move them up to `GenericProtocolServerConnection`.

This looks a little suspicious:
```:geode-core:compileTestJava/home/travis/build/apache/geode/geode-core/src/test/java/org/apache/geode/internal/cache/tier/sockets/ServerConnectionFactoryTest.java:108: error: method makeServerConnection in class ServerConnectionFactory cannot be applied to given types;
    return new ServerConnectionFactory().makeServerConnection(socketMock, mock(InternalCache.class),
                                        ^
  required: Socket,InternalCache,CachedRegionHelper,CacheServerStats,int,int,String,byte,Acceptor,SecurityService
  found: Socket,InternalCache,CachedRegionHelper,CacheServerStats,int,int,String,byte,AcceptorImpl,SecurityService,InetAddress
  reason: actual and formal argument lists differ in length
/home/travis/build/apache/geode/geode-core/src/test/java/org/apache/geode/internal/cache/tier/sockets/ServerConnectionTest.java:85: error: method makeServerConnection in class ServerConnectionFactory cannot be applied to given types;
    serverConnection = new ServerConnectionFactory().makeServerConnection(socket, cache, null, null,
                                                    ^
  required: Socket,InternalCache,CachedRegionHelper,CacheServerStats,int,int,String,byte,Acceptor,SecurityService
  found: Socket,InternalCache,<null>,<null>,int,int,<null>,byte,AcceptorImpl,SecurityService,InetAddress
  reason: actual and formal argument lists differ in length
```
